extracted-table.table-caption: Summary of major findings and associated figures and datasets used in analyses.

caption.p: Summary of major findings and associated figures and datasets used in analyses.

td.xref: 3.1.1. Standard quality control benchmarks across a full range of censoring thresholds

list-item.p: Commonly used DQMs for evaluating resting-state fMRI data quality are poor targets for optimization of motion denoising techniques.

td.xref: 3.1.2. Exploration of confounds in mFD-based dataset-QC metrics

list-item.p: DQMs relying on a relationship between RSFC and SQMs such as mFD (e.g., QC-FC correlations) are confounded by true relationships that exist between SQMs and brain function across subjects

td.italic: HCP Dataset 1, HCP Dataset 1b, HCP Dataset 2, HCP Dataset 2a-c

td.xref: 3.2.1. Mean absolute change in resting state functional connectivity (MAC-RSFC)

list-item.p: MAC-RSFC is a novel summary statistic for evaluating volume censoring methods across censoring parameters that does not depend on SQMs.

Low-pass filtering FD and DV before volume censoring produces superior performance relative to other censoring methods. Run-adaptive censoring of low-pass-filtered DV (GEV-DV censoring) confers further improvements.

td.xref: 3.2.2. Optimization of volume censoring thresholds: A bias-variance decomposition approach

list-item.p: ΔMSE-RSFC allows quantitative optimization of volume censoring parameters in RSFC datasets. Optimal censoring of HCP data results in removal of 40–56% of volumes, but optimal censoring of smaller datasets results in much less data removal.

td.italic: HCP Dataset 1, HCP Dataset 1a, NYSPI Dataset

fn.p: DQM = dataset quality-control metric; fMRI = functional magnetic resonance imaging; HCP = Human Connectome Project; mFD = mean framewise displacement; QC = quality control; RSFC = resting-state functional connectivity; SQM = subject-level quality control metric; QC-FC = quality control-functional connectivity; MAC-RSFC = Mean Absolute Change in Resting-State Functional Connectivity; FD = framewise displacement; DV = temporal derivative root-mean-squared over voxels; GEV-DV = generalized extreme value DV; ΔMSE-RSFC = delta Mean Squared Error-Resting State Functional Connectivity; NYSPI = New York State Psychiatric Institute.

extracted-table.table-caption: Optimal parameters for volume censoring determined by minimizing ΔMSE-RSFC in the HCP500 dataset.

caption.p: Optimal parameters for volume censoring determined by minimizing ΔMSE-RSFC in the HCP500 dataset.

tr.th: Optimal Volume Censoring Parameters for the HCP500 Dataset (HCP Dataset 1)

bold.italic: Combined LPF-FD and GEV-DV Volume Censoring

fn.p: GSR = global signal regression. LPF-FD = low-pass filtered framewise displacement. GEV-DV = generalized extreme value derivative of timecourses, root-mean-squared variance over voxels. All results are from analyses using the HCP 500 dataset (n = 501; HCP Dataset 1).
